@dennismarta true, but it is very hard to get in front of a sea change in investor sentiment. This is why I favor more pure play funds.
6/ And it gets worse when you think of illiquidity in the UST market a la the 10/15/14 meltdown. Not just the vehicle, but market structure
5/ Non-pure play strategies (mix of liquid and illiquid) will always run into trouble in times of stress. Always.
4/ Then, of course, we can have mutual funds putting up gates just like hedge funds. Remember when this happened with The Reserve Fund?
3/ The investment entity needs to correspond to the risk profile. Sadly there is often a mismatch as asset managers want max distribution
2/ There are a wide range of assets held in mutual fund form, with liquidity profiles and demand depth from Treasuries to PE
1/ with the Third Ave. meltdown, it begs the question: are riskier high-yield funds like giant side pockets? Should they be mutual funds?

8/ If they believe one thing (our internal IRRs suck and we should buy back stock with higher ROIC) and say another (we're GROWTH) => bad

6/ But one can't logically argue prima facie that buybacks are bad and internal investment and "transformative M&A" is good
5/ If one should properly value $IBM more as a depleting asset like an oil well than a growth stock, then it's P/E and ROIC will reflect it
4/ Better for investors to deploy perfectly good capital than to have entrenched managements squander it on dumb M&A or internal waste
3/ And if internal growth opportunities aren't that great and if the expected ROIC of a buyback is superior, then by all means do buybacks
2/ Perhaps the only corporate activity more value destroying than buybacks at high prices are "transformative M&A transactions"
1/ The buyback vs. internal investment/M&A analysis is one that should be dynamic and reflect projected returns on capital deployed

@cdixon @mokoyfman @aweissman @pmarca I'm not sure retail should be investing in long-dated locked-up instruments, anyway.
@cdixon @mokoyfman @aweissman @pmarca I think this product already exists. It's called primary+secondary late-stage Growth Equity.
@pointsnfigures @mokoyfman @pmarca I'm sure they wished they traded at much higher multiples, however.
@mokoyfman @pmarca Especially at massive scale. Comparatively tech heavy/asset light business are AWESOME with cont'd innovation+investment
@jfpgaffney @pmarca I believe all investing is "value." How you value business growth vs. FCF/assets is the issue. But everything is *value*
@pmarca @mokoyfman This is why conglomerates seldom work in today's age where the value of "central management" is heavily discounted.
@pmarca @felixsalmon Shutting down businesses to extract value are edge cases. Do they happen? Yes. But comparatively rarely.
@pmarca @felixsalmon All investors want all businesses to be optimized for cash provided there is enough to fund growth. No point otherwise.
@jfpgaffney @pmarca I do not agree. $AAPL is a victim of success. Cash flow=good. They have too much. Keep what's needed, return the balance
@TheStalwart @felixsalmon @pmarca It is also true that what really matters to val is L/T growth rate. Everything else pales in comparison.
@TheStalwart @felixsalmon @pmarca Wrong question. The key is how you perform which leads to being labeled. The right investors will find you
@pmarca The real Q is with $AAPL. Many are thinking about this incorrectly. They need to shed billions in cash, shrink the B/S and refocus
@pmarca You are describing $IBM pre Lou Gerstner. Then he shed assets, went all-in on services, bought back stock and lured back growth inv
@pmarca This requires a blog post. I think there is much more nuance that is important to understanding the investor risk/reward continuum.
@pmarca Important to distinguish between Event-driven and Value-driven arbitrage. Event-driven is short-term. Value-driven can take years.
@pmarca Yes, but it is the transition from Growth to Value that is painful. Sometimes reinvention is possible (e.g., IBM); other times not.
